{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2988418,"name":"Zach Chapman","username":"zec2","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/z/6de8d8/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-10T19:06:34.947Z","cooked":"

Does anyone have any experience with what materials work or don’t work for the structure of climbers placed at the end of the robot (i.e. not over the center of gravity)? In 2018 we built a climber using 2x1x0.125" rectangular extrusion which was fairly successful. This year my team is planning to build a climber with 1" extrusion (https://www.revrobotics.com/1in-extrusion/), which we haven’t used for a climber before. Anyone had any success or failure with it before? If it doesn’t tend to work, what other options are there?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2022-01-10T19:06:34.947Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":29,"reads":374,"readers_count":373,"score":234.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":399497,"topic_slug":"material-for-climbers","display_username":"Zach Chapman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.revrobotics.com/1in-extrusion/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"1" Extrusion - 4ft - REV Robotics","clicks":39}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":43129,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"9309 Mentor, 4550 Alumnus"},"post_url":"/t/material-for-climbers/399497/1","custom_user_title":"9309 Mentor, 4550 Alumnus","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":2988451,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-10T19:56:17.200Z","cooked":"

1’’ box tube is fine; just make sure it’s a decent grade of aluminum (6061 is pretty standard) and that you don’t subject thin-walled (1/16’’) tubing to any large bending moments.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2022-01-10T19:56:37.055Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":332,"readers_count":331,"score":96.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":399497,"topic_slug":"material-for-climbers","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/material-for-climbers/399497/2","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2988472,"name":"Zach Chapman","username":"zec2","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/z/6de8d8/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-10T20:23:53.670Z","cooked":"

It’s not really 1" box tube though, it’s the slotted “X-shaped” extrusion, made of 6063-T5 aluminum. And the bending moment is what I’m most worried about. Because the climber will be positioned at the edge of the robot, I think it will necessarily be subjected to a bending moment since the center of gravity won’t be in line with it, right?

Could share a diagram of what you’re proposing?

We used for those the elevators for the gears from couple of years ago and I can tell you that they bend very easily (even side ways if there’s any uneven load). So I wouldn’t use those for full load support (it’s probably fine if you plan on using them to send a hook up and that has its own load support elsewhere).

Oblarg:

…don’t subject thin-walled (1/16’’) tubing to any large bending moments

This. I’m sure we will see plenty of failures from under-speced material in the name of weight savings.

The best way I can explain it is that it’s similar to the concept ZouKeepers showed in this video, except that the hooks would all be facing the opposite way.

We have struggled with 8020 climbers for a while now. The big issue for us is consistent rigging. We used rope on pulleys, but the rope jumps off the pulley. Or the pulley slides in the extrusion.

We bought a cots climber this year, but we were probably really close last year.

Two things we learned…

  1. Make a channel so the rope cannot jump off the pulleys. We thought of using flat brackets on the outside of the pulley.
  2. Drill through the extrusion so the pulleys do not slide in the groove.

Though we ran out of steam before implementing these changes, I (and some of our members) do think this would work.

I’d avoid that material for a climber both because it’s not very stiff and, perhaps more importantly, because it’s heavy.

I can’t believe nobody has mentioned the 2020 Everybot climber which can scale the MID RUNG as-is with appropriate dimensional tweaks. The PVC can handle a lot of bending, and even if it breaks, you’re hanging from the strap.
